div3.head: Is this a time to dance?

lg.l: The breath of evening sweeps the plain,
And spectrum in the debt,
But on its wings are sounds of pain,
Sad tones that drown the ache's swell,
And yet we hear a mirthful call,
Far pleasure smiles with beaming glance,
Gay me in sounds in the joyous hall--

Oh, God!
is this a time to dance?
Sad notes, as if a spirit sighed,
Float from the crimson battle plain,
As if a mighty spirit cried
In awful agony and pain.
Our friends we know there suffering lay.
Our brothers too, perchance,
And in reposeful accents say,
Loved ones, is this a time to dance?
Oh, lift your festal robes on high!
The human gave that flows around
Will stain their lure with crimson dye,
And yet your mus'd sound.
To drown the dying warrior's cry,
Let sparkling wine your joy enhance--
Forge, at blood has tinged its dye,
And quicker urge the mantle's dance!

But stop!
the floor beneath your feet
Gives back hollow moan,
And every strain of juice sweet
forth soldier's groan.
Oh, sisters who have brothers dear
Expired to every battle's chance,
Bring cask remorse no forms of fear
To fright you from the heartless dance?
Go, fling your festal robes away!
Golden the mourner's table veil!
Go, bow before your God and pray,
If yet your prayers may gh avail.
Go, face the fearful form of death,
And, trembling meet his glance,
And then, for once with truthful breath,
Answer--In this is a time to dance?

div3.head: Proclamation by the President.
div3.p: It is most that at a people who acknowledge the supremacy of the living God, we should be even mindful of our dependence on Him; should remember that to Him alone can we trust for our deliverance; that to Him is due devout thankfulness for the signal bestowed on us; and that by prayer alone can we hope to secure the continued manifestation of that protecting care which has hitherto shielded us in the midst of trials and dangers.

In obedience to His precepts we have from time to time been gathered together with prayers and thanksgiving and He has been graciously pleased to hear our supplications, and to grant abundant exhibition of favor to our armies and our people.
Through many conflicts we have now attained a place among the nations which commands their respect; and to the enemies who encompass us around and seek our destruction the Lord of Hosts has again taught the lesson of His inspired word; That the battle is not to the strong, but to whomsoever He willeth to exalt.

Again our enemy, with loud boasting of the power of their armed and mailed ships threaten us with subjugation, and, with evil machinations, seek even in our own homes and at our own firesides, to pervert our men-servants and our maid-servants into accomplices of their wicked designs.

Under these circumstances it is my privilege to invite you once more to meet together and to prostrate yourselves in humble supplication to Him who has been our constant and never failing support in the past and to whose protection and guidance we trust for the future.

To this end I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do issue this my proclamation, setting apart Friday, the 27th day of March, as a day of fasting, humiliation, and prayer, and I do invite the people of the said States to repair on that day to their usual places of public worship, and to join in prayer to Almighty God that he will continue His merciful protection over our cause, that He will scatter our enemies, and set at naught their evil designs and that He will graciously restore to our beloved country the blessings of peace and security.
In faith whereof I have hereunto set my hand at the city of Richmond on the twenty-seventh day of February, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three.
div3.closer: Jefferson Davis. By the President, J. P. Benjamin, Secretary of State.

div3.head: By the Governor of Virginia — proclamation.

div4.p: --Information having been received by the Executive, that Stephen B Hanley who is charged with horse has escaped from the jail of Henrico court, and is now going at large: therefore, I do hereby offer a reward of Fifty Dollars to any person or persons who shall arrest the said Stephen B Hanley and deliver him into the jail of said county; and I do moreover require all officers of this Commonwealth civil and military, and request the people generally, to use their best exertions to procure the arrest of the said Hanley, that he may be brought to justice.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 25th day of February, in the year 1863.
div4.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
Geo. W. Munford,
Sec'y of the Commonwealth.

div4.p: Stephen B Hanley is six feet high, spare made, dark hair; had on when he escaped a black froes coat dark checked pants and high wool hat; is rather inclined to stoop; is usually spoken or as Capt. Hanley, and is or was recently in services in that capacity.

div3.head: To the General, officers and soldiers of the Southern Army.
div3.p:
--You are respectfully invited to call at my Military Room and take a review of my splendid stock of Trimmings, such a Generals' Wreaths, Stars Sabres Cross Cannons Straps M S. Feathers, Cord and Tassels, Gold Braids of every description Staff and Va Buttons Sword Tassels, &c.--Call and examine for yourself.
You can be fitted up in style at a small expense.
Also, Trimming for Navy Officers
div3.closer:
Miss R. Semon.
No. 30 Main st, two doors below the
St Charles Hospital, up stairs.
Wanted — Gold Epaulets. fe 20--6t*

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the service of the James River and Kanawha Company, about two weeks age, a negro boy named Sam, the property of Col. Wm. P. Munford.
Sem's parents reside in the city, and he is well known here, and is familiar himself with all parts of the city, and is no doubt here.
He is about five feet six inches tall, of a brown color round face, smooth and pleasant countenance.
He has the rheumatism, and is lame in his left knee, which he cannot conceal when walking.
The company will pay $25 reward for the arrest of Sam and his confinement in Gary Street Jail, where I can get him.
div3.closer:
E. L. Chinn,
Supt. J. R. & K. Canal. mh 3--ts

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--$100 reward.--Ran away from the subscriber, on the 18th inst. Annie Banjoes taking with her some $120 in O. S. notes and $120 in gold.
She is in all probability lurking about the city and has been seen near the Medical College, and between that and Victor's said.
The above reward will be paid for her delivery to me in Richmond with the money, or $50 for her alone.
Description, Bright mulatto, about five feet high, and rather stout; aged 17 years; has bushy hair, of a reddish tinge, and large and good front teeth.

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--From the City Gas Works, on the 16th of February, 1863, four negro men — Nat Boyein, Bob Harris, Jim Pollard, and John Rose.
Nat is thick set, dark skin, and five feet four inches high.
Bob is stout, dark skin and five feet seven and a half inches high.
Jim is spare made, dark skin and five feet seven inches high.
John is spare made, dark skin, and five feet seven inches high.
A liberal reward will be paid for the delivery of either or all of them at the City Gas Works.
div3.closer:
Jno. Jerry,
Superintendent. fe 26--6t*

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and securing, so that I get them of two negroes, Taylor and Rosa, who left my premises about the 1st of May, 1862, or $50 for either of them.
Taylor is about 15 years old dark skin, very quick and sprightly, and I understand was with Capt. Mitchell, of the 11th Ga. reg't, last June and now supposed to be somewhere in Gen. Longstreet's corps, if not with that regiment, and passes by the name of "Free Bill." Rosa is 22 years old a likely mulatto, a scar on the cheek caused by a burnt believed to be harbored in this city.
Information left with W. S. Phillips, 12th street, or Dr. P. W. Hancock, Main street, between 3d and 4th

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Lost from the subscriber, on or about the 27th of February, 1863, a negro boy, who answers to the name of Pick.
Said boy is 22 years old; 5 feet 8 inches high, and complexion black.
He had on when he left a dark jeans coat and jacket.
I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and confinement, or for his delivery to me, at Quinea's Station.
div3.closer:
Wm. L. Stevenson Co. A,
4th reg't N. C. S. T. mh 5--3t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--A young negro man, named John Chisman, who came to Richmond from Williamsburg some time last spring, and who has been hired about the city until recently, has disappeared.
Fifty dollars reward will be paid by Messrs. Blair & Chamberlayne, on Main street, if the negro shall be delivered to them, or secured in jail in Richmond to their order.
The man is about 22 years old, black, about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches tall, and quite likely.
Mr. Parkes Slater, south side of Broad street between 4th and 5th, can give information as to the acquaintance of the man amongst his own color, &c.

closer.signed: Robt. A. Bright, C. S. A.

div3.p:
I will pay a liberal reward for the arrest and delivery to me or confinement in some jail so that I may get him, of my man Stokes, who left my house, in Amelia county, on the 18th of January, and is evidently attempting to make his escape to the Yankees, or has hired himself to work in some camp.
Stokes is about 23 years of age, 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, black complexion, and has a large scar on his side, occasioned by a burn.
div3.closer:
Mary A. Hardaway.
Deatonville P. O. Amelia co. fe 18--6t*

div3.head: Forty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Left my farm near Keysville in Charlotte co. Va. on Sunday, the 15th instant, my negro man George Braxton.
I bought him of Dickinson, Hill & Co. as the property of Thos A. Lacy, New Kent co. Va.
in December last.
His wife lives near Mr. Lacy's, where, I suppose, he is making his way. He is a little under the medium height black, has fell whiskers, speaks rather indistinctly; had on when he left a Yankee blue overcoat and vest, black hat and patched pants.
He is about 35 years old. I will give $30 reward for him if taken between my house and Richmond, and brought to my house, or $40 if taken in Richmond or beyond that place, and lodged in jail in Richmond so that I get him again

div3.head: Twenty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the return of a small negro boy named Peter, or for any information given so that I can get him. He left my house, on Union Hill, about the 25th of January.
It is very likely he may report himself free, and apply to some of the hospitals or camps around Richmond for employment.
He has a scar under his chin from scrofula, and one also over one eye, and is about 14 years of age.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from Wylliesburg, in Charlotte county, during the month of June, 1862, my man Bartlett.
For his apprehension and delivery to me, if taken up out of the State, I will pay the above reward; if captured within the State, and placed in jail so that I can get him I will pay $50 Bartlett is about 20 years of age, of small stature, weighing, perhaps, 130 pounds; 5 feet 5 inches high, mahogany color, one upper tooth out in front, low forehead, and dull countenance.
When last seen he was in the vicinity of Clarksville.
div3.closer:
A. G. Jeffery,
Red. Oak Grove, Va. fe 13--10t

div3.head: Ran away--$100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from "Wakefield," the farm in Hanover next adjoining Mr. Geo. W. Doswell's, on Monday, the 9th instant, a negro man named Jim. Said negro is of dark complexion, 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high, about 23 years old, and has a defect in his right eye. He was dressed in gray clothes, and had on either boots or wooden bottomed yellow shoes.
Before leaving he spoke of going to the Junction to get with our army and I especially request quartermasters and wagon-masters on the lines of the Central of Fredericksburg Railroads to keep a look-out for him. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension and delivery in the jail at Hanover Court House, so that I get him again; or to myself in Richmond.
div3.closer:
E. W. Richardson,
Ex'r of Mrs. Judith Smith, dec'd. fe 11--d5t&sw4t*

div3.head: Runaway in jail.
div3.p:
--Was committed to the jail of Henrico county, as a runaway a negro boy named Jim, as the property of John Montgomery, of the county of York, Va. The said boy is about 18 years old, 5 feet 7 inches high, with brown skin; had on when committed a full suit of grey Virginia clothing.
The owner of said boy is requested to come forward, prove property, pay charges and take him away, or he will be dealt with as the law directs.

closer.signed: Geo. D. Pleasants, S. H. C.

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on the 27th inst., a black Girl, about 14 years old not very good teeth in front.
She was purchased of Mrs. Mary W. Coleman, of Carolina county, and may be making her way back.
I will pay $25 for her arrest and delivery to Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 25th Dec'd last my negro man Patrick.
He is about 28 years of age, about five feet, seven inches high, very black, large thick lips, his under one turns entirely over, and large feet and hands.
He has in driving to the city of Richmond for several years past.--He may be lurking about the city, or in some of the camps around.
I will give the above reward for his apprehension and return to me.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, on or about the 25th of July, 1862, from the camp of the 7th Georgia my negro boy, Isaac, frequently called Monk; aged 21 years 5 feet 5 inches high, copper colored, large eyes, quick spoken, quick gait.
When last heard from he was hiring himself as a free negro.
Any person who can arrest him and lodge him in any safe jail so that I can get him shall have the above reward.

div3.head: Twenty five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway about the 15th of February, a black man named Miles, about 22 years old. He was purchased of W. H. Pleasants, on the 10th instant.
I will pay the above reward for his delivery to Messrs Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: Two hundred and Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For my woman Vina who escaped from the Bollingbrook Hotel, in Petersburg, the 12th of Jan'y. She had on a homespun dress.
She is about 25 years old, dark skin.
She was hired to Mr. Jno. Donnan, in Petersburg, in 1862.--I bought her from Mr. Alpheus A. Rowlett, in Chesterfield.
She may be harbored by some person in or near Petersburg.
If so, I will give $50 in addition to the above reward for their detection.
If caught, she may be placed in jail in Petersburg or Richmond.
Address any information concerning her to H. A. Pharce, Richmond, Va, or Mr. Robt F. Jackson, at the office of the South-Side railroad, Petersburg, Va.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Absconded from my farm, near Ashland, Hanover county, about the 15th of December last, my man Job, about 28 or 30 years of age, black complexion, 5 feet 6 or 7 inches high.
He was purchased by me in Richmond last fall, and formerly belonged to Wm. Woodfin Cumberland county, about whose place he is supposed to be in king.
I will pay the above reward if delivered to C. W. Coleman, near Ashland, or lodged in some jail so I get him again.
div3.closer:
W. A. Dick.
Ashland, Hanover county, February 13, 1863, fe 14--2taw4w*

div3.head:
Camp near Guinea's Station,
March 5, 1863.
div3.p: The Government reward will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to Capt. Alexander, Castle Thunder, of the following named deserters from my company!
Martin Sullivan, a substitute, 5 feet 6 inches high, dark hair, gray eyes, dark complexion, born in Ireland, and 45 years of age.
Samuel Roberts, gray eyes, florid complexion, born in Ireland, and 46 years of age; had on a new gray jacket when he deserted.
Thomas Conner., a substitute, 5 feet 7 inches high, dark hair, gray eyes, dark complexion, born in Ireland, and 46 years of age.
William Moore, a substitute, 5 feet 9 inches high, light hair, gray eyes, dark complexion, born in Ireland, and 47 years of age.
All of the above substitutes were received by Maj. W. Peyton, Camp Lee in January and February last.
div3.closer:
C. A. Davidson, Capt. Co. E,
1st Virginia Battalion,
Lt. Gen. Jackson Corp'l. mh 6--2t*

div3.head:
Headq'r Departm't of Henrico,
Richmond Va., March 5, 1863.
div3.p: Notice.--All communications in relation to paragraph VIII. Special Orders No. 13, Adjutant and inspector General's Office, March 4, 1863, will be addressed to the Assistant Adjutant General of this Department.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig.-Gen. John H. Winder, Commanding Department.
J. W. Pegram, A. A. G. mh 6--6t

div3.head:
Office of Board of Furgross
for attending sick officers in
private quarters.
div3.p: All officers registered as patients in private quarters since the 20th day of January last are hereby notified that unless heard from within ten days after the publication of this notice they will be reported to their respective commanders as fit for duty.
div3.closer:
A. Y. P. Garnett,
Surgeon.
Office corner of 11th and Broad streets. mh 4--0

div3.head: Two hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--For the apprehension and delivery to me of Frederick Reem, who enlisted in my company as a substitute on the 13th of January, 1863, to serve for the war. Said Palm is a German about 5 feet 7 inches high, light hair, blue eyes, fair complexion, and represents himself to be 45 years old. He has a fresh scar over the right eye also on both thighs from an old wound.
Said from Richmond, and is supposed to have returned to that city, or to be in the neighborhood of the Bowling Green, where he's said to have been formerly employed as maker I will pay the above reward for his delivery to me, or $10 if confined in any Confederate prison, so that I get him again.
div3.closer:
A. Capt. Co. F.
45th Va. Field's Brigade,
A. P. Hill's Division. fe 28--13t*

div3.head:
Headq'r Company K. 21st Va. Reg't.
February 24th, 1863.
div3.p: Fifty Dollars reward.--The usual reward of $30, with an addition of $20 for either or of the following named men, will be paid if delivered to me, or confined where I can get them viz: Recadah Danton, Richard A. Dunnsvant, and Francis D. Atwell, who deserted my company on the 9th of December, 1862, near Guinea Slatton, Va.

All members of my company now absent who do not report at once, or read Surgeon's certificate of disability will be considered as deserters and treated as such.
Those on furlough are required to report as soon as their furloughs are out.
div3.closer:
Henry H. Roach,
Lt Com'g Co. K. 21st Va. Reg't,
Camp Corbin's Neck, Carolina county, Va. fe 28--3t*

div3.head:
Camp near Port Royal,
January 30, 1863.
div3.p: Arrest the Deserters — The usual reward of $30 will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me, or to the officer in command of Castle Thunder, Richmond city, of the following deserters from Company "A." 8th Regiment Louisiana Volunteers.

list.item: 1. Private Jas Hoyd, a native of Ireland, about 32 years of age, red hair and beard, ruddy complexion, marked by the small pox, somewhat over 6 feet height, and a teamster by pation. He is supposed to have joined a Virginia cavalry company.
2. Private Jno. H. Cumming, a native of New York State, 21 years old, light hair, no beard, complexion, blue eyes, about 5 feet 7 inches high, and a painter by trade.
3. Private Patrick Donahoe, a native of Ireland, about 37 years old, light black hair, ruddy complexion, quick of speech and motion, about 9 feet 5½ inches high, and a gardener by trade.
4. Private Patrick Fitzgerald, a native of Ireland, near 40 years of age, black hair and beard slightly bald, black eyes, about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, and a day

5. Private Wm. Bragan, a native of New York State, 30 years old, auburn hair, hazel eyes, stout built, some 5 feet 7 inches high, and a blacksmith by trade.
He asserted in the early part of last June, and is supposed to be in Richmond city, as I lately received a notice from Capt. West, one of the Quartermasters of that city, that he had paid him $174.58 as pay, bounty, and clothing money.

div3.p: I will add $20 for Reagan's arrest, thus making the reward in his case $50.
div3.closer:
A. L. Gusman,
Capt. co. A, 8th Esq. La. Vols. fe 6--5t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --In accordance with special orders No. 39, from the Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, I am now in Powhatan on recruiting service, and announce the partial suspension of the Conscript law, so as to permit conscripts to volunteer in the companies of their own selection, without passing through camps of instruction, and to receive the bounty and other benefits provided by law for volunteers.

It is useless for me to make an appeal to your patriotism.
The desolate condition of the fairest portion of your State speaks in stronger terms than anything I would say, Come forward, then, one and all, and volunteer at once, that the vile invader may be swept from the sacred of your native State.
Any one within the conscript age who will come forward and volunteer will have the privilege of attaching himself to any company he may select, and will be furnished with transportation to the company on application to me. He will also receive $50 bounty and all other benefits provided by law in such cases
div3.closer:
F. S. Hosey,
Capt and Recruiting Officer. fe 10--2sw4w

div3.head: Three hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p:
I will pay $300 in cash to any one who will arrest Michael Rooney, who deserted from my company last night after having regularly entered as a substitute three days before.
He is a short, thick built Irishman and wise, when he left, a pair of blue Yankee pants, citizen's coat, and a black wool hat, badly wort; he is 46 or 47 years old and has generally worked on railroads, he once lived in Alexandria; has recently lived in Richmond, where it is said he has a wife and two children.
The above reward will be paid to any one who will lodge him in Castle Thunder or any other prison, and notify me of the same or for his head, should he resist arrest.
div3.closer:
Wm. T. Nicholson,
Capt. comd'g co. E. 37th N. C. Reg't.,
Lane's Brigade, A. P. Hill's Div.
February 20th 1863. fe 24--2w

div3.head: Five hundred Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from comp'y M. 26th Virginia reg't., on the 1st inst., Henry Scott, an Irishman, about 47 years old about 5 feet 6½ inches high; dark-brown or black hair; bluish eyes; dark complexion; has a ship tattooed on his breast, a woman on each arm, the woman on the left arm has a child in her arms; has a star on the back of the left hand, and has lost a portion of the middle finger of the right hand.--Henry Scott was mustered as a substitute for Robt Edmundson, of Halifax co. Va. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me at the camp of the 26th Virginia regiment, Wise's brigade, near Chaffin's Bluff.
div3.closer:
John T. Perein, Capt. Co. B.
26th Virginia regiment. fe 20--11t*

div3.head: Ninety Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from George Bulls aged 46 years, complexion dark, hair dark and slightly gray, eyes blue, height 5 feet 4½ inches, bottom front teeth large and irregular, supposed to be lurking about Chesterfield Coal Pits.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery at Castle Thunder.

div3.head: Notice to conscripts.
div3.p: --The Medical Examining Board for the 3d Congressional District is now holding its session at the Camp of instruction, near Richmond.
All persons of conscript age, who have been authorised to appear before this Board for final examination, will report immediately

closer.signed: John A. Coke, Capt. and Enroll'g Officer
